I don't know, recording voice notes feels natural."
gpt_3_5_turbo_instruct_response:

Pragmatic: The intended meaning of "whatever you think" and "natural" could vary depending on the context and tone. 
Vagueness: The phrase "I don't know" could be seen as vague as it does not provide a clear reason or explanation.

2. Syntactic: the phrase "Option to hide reblogs from people you follow" can be interpreted in multiple ways. It is not clear if it refers to hiding reblogs from people you already follow or from people who follow you.

4. Pragmatic: it is not specified what purpose the requester has in wanting to hide reblogs, which could affect the implementation of this option.

5. Vagueness: the request does not specify which "dropdown" on profiles the option should be available in.

FeatureRequestText: Request Number: 147 - Request Title: don't change the position after new posts were loaded - Request Description: If I am on the top of my timeline I pull down to load new posts. The focus will then be moved to the top of the list to show the newest post. I then have to read down until I see (if I remember) the last post I read before the reload.In my opinion it would be way more comfortable and consistent to not change the position here, just put the new posts above and let the user read on in the same direction. (Upwards)Thanks!

The focus will then be moved to the top of the list to show the newest post. I then have to read down until I see (if I remember) the last post I read before the reload.In my opinion it would be way more comfortable and consistent to not change the position here, just put the new posts above and let the user read on in the same direction. (Upwards)Thanks!"
gpt_3_5_turbo_instruct_response:
1. Lexical ambiguity: "posts" could refer to both social media posts and support posts (as in a technical support forum)
2. Syntactic ambiguity: The phrase "don't change the position" could be interpreted as both the physical position of the user or the position of the posts in the timeline.
3. Semantic ambiguity: The term "comfortable" is not clearly defined and could have different meanings to different people.
4. Pragmatic ambiguity: The request title and description do not fully clarify the purpose or intended outcome of the request.
5. Vagueness: The description of scrolling down and reading until the user remembers the last post read before the reload is not specific and could lead to confusion.

FeatureRequestText: Request Number: 158 - Request Title: Block tags - Request Description: As a user I would like to be able to block certain tags from my time-line so I don't have to deal with unwanted content (either stuff that's annoying, spammy or straight offensive). In contrast to user- or domain-based blocks, this is a bit more fine grained (e.g. I might like a user in general but I don't care about their daily cat picture).PS: Thank you for providing and maintaining this great piece of software!

In contrast to user- or domain-based blocks, this is a bit more fine grained (e.g. I might like a user in general but I don't care about their daily cat picture).PS: Thank you for providing and maintaining this great piece of software!"
gpt_3_5_turbo_instruct_response:
1. Lexical ambiguity: The word "block" can have multiple meanings, such as physically obstructing something or preventing it from being seen.
2. Syntactic ambiguity: The phrase "block tags" could be interpreted as either blocking tags from being seen or using tags to block something.
3. Semantic ambiguity: The term "fine grained" is not clearly defined and could have different meanings.
4. Pragmatic ambiguity: The sentence "I might like a user in general but I don't care about their daily cat picture" could be interpreted as the user not liking the person's cat pictures, or not caring about them at all.
5. Vagueness: The term "certain tags" and "unwanted content" are not specifically defined, leaving room for interpretation.
